text:
E37/829  is  within  the  Kurnalpi  Terrane  of  Cassidy  et  al.  (2006).  This  terrane  was  originally 
 defined  by  Swager  (1997)  but  has  since  been  expanded  to  include  the  former  Gindalbie  and 
 Laverton Terranes. It is currently defined as being bounded by the Ockerburry Fault System to 
 the west and the Hootanui Fault System to the east. A significant part of this revised definition is 
 the separation of the former Gindalbie terrane into north and south components. The Kurnalpi 
 Terrane is now considered to comprise of the Bulong, Gindalbie, Menangina, Murrin, Laverton, 
 Edjudina and Linden Domains. 
 This terrane comprises a series of thin, linear north-north-west trending fault bounded domains 
 of dominantly mafic-felsic volcanic sequences with prominent lateral facies changes. Komatiite 
 horizons  are  thin  and  discontinuous,  and more common  in the  Bulong and  Laverton  domains. 
 Locally regions of calc-alkaline volcanic, epiclastic deposits and BIF are found. 
 Gindalbie Domain 
 Cassidy  et  al.  (2006)  divide  the  Kurnalpi  terrane  into  seven  domains,  the  Bulong,  Gindalbie, 
 Menangina, Murrin, Laverton, Edjudina and Linden Domains. The Gindalbie Domain comprises 
 the  northern  portion  of  Swager’s  (1997)  Gindalbie  Terrane.  It  is  bounded  on  the  west  by  the 
 Ockerburry  Fault  System  and  on the  east  by  the  Emu  and  Kilkenny  Fault  Systems  and to  the 
 south by a complex faulted boundary with the Bulong Domain. 
 The  Gindalbie  Domain  represents  a  bimodal  mafic  and  felsic  volcanic  sequence.  Felsic 
 volcanics (dominantly dacite and rhyolite) increase higher in the sequence. 
 Economic  concentrations  of  the  base  metals,  Cu,  Pb  and  Zn,  are  not  common  in  the  eastern 
 Yilgarn. However deposits which have been discovered occur in the Gindalbie Domain, of which 
 Jaguar South project area can be considered a part. The bimodal basalt-rhyolite volcanism and 
 the  interpreted  extensional  tectonic  environment  are  consistent  with  models  for  Archean  and 
 younger stratabound massive sulphide deposits (Witt, 1994). Of relevance is the Teutonic Bore 
 (2.15 Mt at 3.53% Cu, 11.39% Zn and 150g/t Ag) and Jaguar (1.81 Mt at 3.3% Cu, 10.8% Zn 
 7

6.text: The  Jaguar  South  Project  lies  within  the  Eastern  Goldfields  Superterrane,  which  has  been

text: The  Jaguar  South  Project  lies  within  the  Eastern  Goldfields  Superterrane,  which  has  been

29.text: The  sequence  dips  to  the  west  at  approximately  75  degrees  and  young's  to  the  west.  The

30.text: regional  strike  is  north-north-west  as  is  the  pronounced  regional foliation.  Strike faulting  is  not

31.text: obvious  due  to  limited  outcrop,  but  a  major  shear  structure  can  be  observed  west  of Wilson's

32.text: Bore and can be traced for several kilometers north. This structure appears to link with a major

33.text: fault/shear to the west which marks the western limit of the tectonic zone.

35.text: West-north-west  trending  faults  are  numerous  throughout  the  region.  Dips  vary  from

36.text: approximately 45 degrees south to 45 degrees north; these structures can be observed to off-

37.text: set the main basalt-felsic volcanic contact and may be the expression of growth faulting during

38.text: the deformation in the tectonic zone. Displacement is mostly sinistral, but dextral off-sets of the

39.text: felsic - mafic contact can also be observed. Folding is not well exposed being restricted to small

40.text: scale folds within sedimentary horizons or within shears.

text:
The  sequence  dips  to  the  west  at  approximately  75  degrees  and  young's  to  the  west.  The 
 regional  strike  is  north-north-west  as  is  the  pronounced  regional foliation.  Strike faulting  is  not 
 obvious  due  to  limited  outcrop,  but  a  major  shear  structure  can  be  observed  west  of Wilson's 
 Bore and can be traced for several kilometers north. This structure appears to link with a major 
 fault/shear to the west which marks the western limit of the tectonic zone. 
 West-north-west  trending  faults  are  numerous  throughout  the  region.  Dips  vary  from 
 approximately 45 degrees south to 45 degrees north; these structures can be observed to off-
 set the main basalt-felsic volcanic contact and may be the expression of growth faulting during 
 the deformation in the tectonic zone. Displacement is mostly sinistral, but dextral off-sets of the 
 felsic - mafic contact can also be observed. Folding is not well exposed being restricted to small 
 scale folds within sedimentary horizons or within shears.

10.text: area is covered by transported material with smaller areas of good outcrop that indicate the area

11.text: is a complex lithological sequence and a protracted deformation history.

13.text: The  Jaguar  South  area  comprises  a  mafic  unit  of  pillow  basalts,  dolerites  and  gabbros

14.text: interbedded with thick beds of silicic volcaniclastic rocks and rhyolite lava (Brown et al., 2001).

15.text: These felsic volcanic rocks, which show schistose to massive textures, are conformably overlain

16.text: by a sequence of sedimentary layers, derived from the felsic volcanic units with minor shale and

17.text: chert. Dolerite bodies intrude all levels of the stratigraphy.

19.text: Compositionally  similar  syenogranite  and  alkali-feldspar  granite  associated  with  this  complex,

20.text: and  outcrop  in  the  north  eastern  extents  of  the  area  are  probably  genetically  related  to  the

text:
area is covered by transported material with smaller areas of good outcrop that indicate the area 
 is a complex lithological sequence and a protracted deformation history. 
 The  Jaguar  South  area  comprises  a  mafic  unit  of  pillow  basalts,  dolerites  and  gabbros 
 interbedded with thick beds of silicic volcaniclastic rocks and rhyolite lava (Brown et al., 2001). 
 These felsic volcanic rocks, which show schistose to massive textures, are conformably overlain 
 by a sequence of sedimentary layers, derived from the felsic volcanic units with minor shale and 
 chert. Dolerite bodies intrude all levels of the stratigraphy. 
 Compositionally  similar  syenogranite  and  alkali-feldspar  granite  associated  with  this  complex, 
 and  outcrop  in  the  north  eastern  extents  of  the  area  are  probably  genetically  related  to  the

4.2 EM SURVEY 
 Rubicon Resources Ltd contracted Southern Geoscience Consultants to conduct a MLTEM (moving 
 loop  TEM)  survey  over  the  ground  held  by  the  Jaguar  South  Project  in  E37/829.  The  survey 
 proceeded on the 4th of July 2007 for a total of 5 flight lines with a 400m spacing between each line, 
 as tabulated below in Table 4.

 The Jaguar South Project located in the Kalgoorlie Terrane of the Archean Yilgarn Craton has 
 potential  to  host  gold  and  VMS  style  base  metal  deposits  associated  with  structures  and  host 
 From the work done during the reporting period, which included data compilation and  MLTEM 
 survey, discouraging results concluded that there is minimal potential for surface or near surface 
 VMS  deposits  as  there  was  a  lack  of  good  anomalies  to  indicate  the  presence  of  massive 
 sulphides in the area bound by E37/829. 
 No further work has been planned for the area.
